questions.explanation: The sphingolipid rheostat model proposes that cell fate decisions (survival vs. death) are determined by the relative levels of three interconvertible sphingolipid metabolites: (1) Ceramide: a pro-apoptotic/growth-inhibitory lipid generated by sphingomyelinase (from sphingomyelin) or de novo synthesis. Ceramide activates PP2A (dephosphorylating Akt), cathepsin D, and mitochondrial channels, promoting apoptosis. Stress signals (UV, chemotherapy, TNF) increase ceramide. (2) Sphingosine: generated from ceramide by ceramidase. Sphingosine inhibits PKC and promotes apoptosis. (3) Sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P): generated from sphingosine by sphingosine kinase (SphK1/2). S1P signals through five GPCRs (S1PR1-5) to activate survival pathways (PI3K/Akt, ERK), promote cell migration, and regulate immune cell trafficking. Growth factor signaling activates SphK1, shifting the balance toward S1P. The enzyme sphingosine kinase controls this conversion and is considered oncogenic (SphK1 overexpression promotes tumor growth). FTY720 (fingolimod), an S1P receptor modulator, is used for multiple sclerosis treatment. The rheostat concept has been validated by showing that shifting the ceramide/S1P balance (genetically or pharmacologically) predictably shifts cells between survival and death.

questions.question: What distinguishes type I and type II cytokine receptors from receptor tyrosine kinases?
options: RTKs lack kinase activity and associate with JAKs, while cytokine receptors have intrinsic kinase domains
There is no structural or functional difference between them

Cytokine receptors lack intrinsic kinase activity but constitutively associate with Janus kinases (JAKs) that provide the tyrosine kinase function; RTKs have intrinsic kinase domains built into the receptor polypeptide itself
Cytokine receptors only bind steroid hormones
questions.explanation: This is a fundamental distinction in receptor biology. Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs, e.g., EGFR, PDGFR, FGFR) are single-pass transmembrane proteins with an intrinsic tyrosine kinase domain encoded as part of the receptor polypeptide. Ligand-induced dimerization brings two kinase domains together for trans-autophosphorylation. Cytokine receptors (type I: receptors for IL-2, IL-6, GM-CSF, GH, erythropoietin; type II: receptors for interferons, IL-10) also respond to ligand-induced dimerization/multimerization, but they LACK any catalytic domain. Instead, they constitutively associate with JAK family tyrosine kinases (JAK1, JAK2, JAK3, TYK2) through their cytoplasmic Box1/Box2 motifs. When the receptor dimerizes, the pre-associated JAKs are brought into proximity, trans-phosphorylate each other (activating), and then phosphorylate tyrosine residues on the receptor cytoplasmic tails. These phosphotyrosines recruit STAT transcription factors via SH2 domains. Despite the mechanistic similarity (both result in tyrosine phosphorylation of the receptor), the architectural distinction — intrinsic vs. associated kinase — defines different receptor superfamilies with different evolutionary origins and regulatory properties.

questions.question: What is the physiological consequence of constitutive activation of the Hedgehog pathway due to Patched (Ptc) loss-of-function mutations?
options: No phenotype; Ptc loss is compensated by other receptors
Ptc loss increases sensitivity to Hedgehog ligand but does not cause constitutive activation
Ptc loss activates apoptosis, reducing tissue size

Ptc loss removes the constitutive inhibition of Smoothened, leading to ligand-independent pathway activation, Gli-mediated transcription of target genes, and uncontrolled cell proliferation — causing basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma (Gorlin syndrome in hereditary cases)
questions.explanation: Patched (PTCH1) is the receptor for Hedgehog ligands and also the primary negative regulator of the pathway. In its unliganded state, Ptch constitutively inhibits Smoothened (Smo), keeping the pathway OFF. Loss-of-function mutations in PTCH1 eliminate this inhibition, causing constitutive Smoothened activation and ligand-independent pathway signaling: Gli transcription factors (particularly Gli2A) accumulate in the nucleus and activate target genes including PTCH1 itself (which cannot provide negative feedback if both alleles are lost), GLI1, CCND1 (cyclin D1), MYC, and BCL2. This drives uncontrolled proliferation and survival. Clinically: (1) Gorlin syndrome (basal cell nevus syndrome): autosomal dominant disorder caused by germline PTCH1 mutations; patients develop multiple basal cell carcinomas at young ages, medulloblastomas, and skeletal abnormalities. (2) Sporadic basal cell carcinoma: ~90% have somatic PTCH1 mutations or Smo activating mutations. (3) ~30% of sporadic medulloblastomas have Hh pathway mutations. The FDA-approved drug vismodegib (GDC-0449) inhibits Smoothened and is used to treat advanced basal cell carcinoma, validating the pathway as a therapeutic target.

questions.question: Exosomes and extracellular vesicles represent a recently discovered mode of cell-cell communication. What signals can they transmit?
options: Exosomes are small (30-150 nm) membrane-bound vesicles released by cells that carry proteins, mRNAs, microRNAs, and lipids to recipient cells, enabling transfer of functional molecules and reprogramming of recipient cell gene expression
Exosomes can only transfer lipids between cells
Exosomes are artifacts of cell culture with no physiological function
Exosomes only transport waste products for disposal
questions.explanation: Exosomes and extracellular vesicles (EVs) represent an intercellular communication system discovered in recent decades. Exosomes (30-150 nm) originate from the endosomal pathway: inward budding of late endosome/multivesicular body (MVB) membranes creates intraluminal vesicles that are released when the MVB fuses with the plasma membrane. They carry: (1) Proteins: surface ligands (PD-L1, MHC, tetraspanins), signaling proteins, enzymes; (2) Nucleic acids: mRNAs that can be translated in recipient cells, microRNAs (miRNAs) that can silence target genes in recipients, and long non-coding RNAs; (3) Lipids: bioactive lipids including ceramide, S1P, and prostaglandins. Exosomes are taken up by recipient cells via membrane fusion, endocytosis, or receptor-mediated uptake. Functions include: immune modulation (dendritic cell exosomes presenting antigens to T cells), tumor microenvironment communication (cancer exosomes promoting angiogenesis and pre-metastatic niche formation via miRNA transfer), neural communication, and stem cell signaling. Exosomes are being explored as biomarkers (liquid biopsy) and drug delivery vehicles.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about apoptosis signaling:

S1: The intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway is triggered by intracellular stress (DNA damage, growth factor withdrawal, ER stress) and converges on mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization (MOMP) controlled by Bcl-2 family proteins.
S2: Cytochrome c released from mitochondria binds Apaf-1, forming the apoptosome, which activates caspase-9 (initiator caspase), which then activates caspase-3/7 (effector caspases).
S3: The extrinsic and intrinsic pathways are completely independent and never cross-talk.
S4: IAPs (inhibitor of apoptosis proteins, e.g., XIAP) can directly inhibit caspases, and Smac/DIABLO (released from mitochondria during MOMP) antagonizes IAPs to promote apoptosis.
options: TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
TTTF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The intrinsic pathway is activated by intracellular damage signals that induce BH3-only proteins: DNA damage → p53 → Puma/Noxa; growth factor withdrawal → Bim/Bad (dephosphorylated); ER stress → Bim/Puma. BH3-only proteins activate Bax/Bak, which oligomerize in the mitochondrial outer membrane (MOM), forming large pores (MOMP). This releases intermembrane space proteins including cytochrome c, Smac/DIABLO, and Omi/HtrA2 into the cytoplasm. S2 is TRUE: Released cytochrome c binds Apaf-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor 1), inducing its oligomerization into a wheel-shaped heptameric complex — the apoptosome (~1.4 MDa). The apoptosome recruits and activates procaspase-9 by induced proximity, generating active caspase-9. Caspase-9 then cleaves and activates the executioner caspases-3 and -7, which cleave hundreds of cellular substrates (PARP, ICAD, lamin A) to execute apoptosis. S3 is FALSE: The extrinsic and intrinsic pathways CROSS-TALK. The key connection is Bid (a BH3-only protein): caspase-8 (from the extrinsic DISC) cleaves Bid to tBid, which activates Bax/Bak and triggers MOMP. In 'type II' cells (hepatocytes), this amplification loop through mitochondria is essential for death receptor-induced apoptosis. Bcl-2 overexpression blocks apoptosis in type II cells (by blocking MOMP) but not type I cells (which have sufficient DISC-generated caspase-8). S4 is TRUE: IAPs (XIAP is the most potent) contain BIR domains that directly bind and inhibit caspase-3, -7, and -9. Smac/DIABLO (released from mitochondria during MOMP) contains an AVPI tetrapeptide motif that competes with caspases for IAP BIR domain binding, relieving IAP inhibition. This dual safety mechanism (apoptosome activation + IAP neutralization) ensures robust caspase activation. Smac-mimetic drugs (birinapant, LCL-161) are being developed as cancer therapeutics.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the Notch signaling pathway:

S1: Notch activation requires physical cell-cell contact because both receptor (Notch) and ligands (Delta/Jagged) are transmembrane proteins on adjacent cells.
S2: The mechanical pulling force generated by endocytosis of Delta-Notch-bound complex in the signal-sending cell is essential for exposing the S2 cleavage site on Notch.
S3: Gamma-secretase cleaves Notch within the transmembrane domain (S3 cleavage), releasing NICD that enters the nucleus and directly binds DNA without any partner.
S4: Notch signaling is a rapid, enzyme-catalyzed signal amplification cascade similar to the MAPK cascade.
options: TTTF
TTFF
TFTT
TTFT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Notch signaling is the prototypical juxtacrine (contact-dependent) pathway. Both the receptor (Notch 1-4) and ligands (Delta-like 1/3/4, Jagged 1/2) are single-pass transmembrane proteins, requiring direct cell-cell contact for activation. This proximity requirement restricts Notch signaling to adjacent cells, enabling pattern formation through lateral inhibition. S2 is TRUE: Trans-endocytosis of the extracellular domain of Notch bound to Delta by the signal-sending cell generates a mechanical pulling force (~12 pN) that unfolds the Notch negative regulatory region (NRR), exposing the ADAM10/TACE S2 cleavage site. Without this force, the NRR normally conceals the cleavage site, preventing ligand-independent activation. This mechanosensitive gating ensures that Notch is only activated by membrane-bound ligands on adjacent cells (trans-activation) and not by soluble ligands. S3 is FALSE: While gamma-secretase does cleave Notch at S3 releasing NICD, the NICD does NOT directly bind DNA. NICD enters the nucleus and binds the transcription factor CSL (CBF1/RBPjkappa/Su(H)/Lag-1), which provides the DNA-binding specificity. NICD converts CSL from a transcriptional repressor (associated with co-repressor complexes) to an activator by displacing co-repressors and recruiting co-activators (Mastermind/MAML, p300). S4 is FALSE: Notch signaling is notably NOT an amplification cascade. It lacks enzymatic amplification: one receptor activation releases one NICD molecule, which forms one transcriptional complex. There is no kinase cascade or second messenger amplification. This 'one signal, one response' stoichiometry makes Notch signaling relatively low-gain, requiring multiple Notch-Delta interactions for robust responses. Signal intensity is controlled by receptor/ligand levels and post-translational modifications (Fringe glycosylation of Notch modulates ligand specificity).

questions.question:
Researchers use optogenetic tools to activate Ras with precise temporal control (light-activated Ras, OptoSOS). They measure ERK phosphorylation in response to different stimulation patterns:

| Stimulation pattern | Duration | p-ERK at 30 min |
|--------------------|----------|------------------|
| Continuous light ON | 30 min | +++ (high) |
| 1 min ON / 4 min OFF (pulsed) | 30 min total | ++ (moderate) |
| 1 min ON / 9 min OFF (pulsed) | 30 min total | + (low) |
| 5 min ON then OFF | 30 min | 0 (returned to basal) |
| 10 min ON then OFF | 30 min | 0 (returned to basal) |

Pulsed stimulation (rows 2-3) maintains p-ERK at intermediate levels even though Ras is OFF most of the time. What does this reveal about the MAPK cascade dynamics?
options: The multi-tiered MAPK cascade acts as a temporal integrator that smooths pulsatile input into a sustained output; the kinase activation/deactivation kinetics at each tier (Raf→MEK→ERK→phosphatase) create a low-pass filter that converts pulsed Ras activation into time-averaged ERK output proportional to the duty cycle
The MAPK cascade has no memory; each pulse is independent
ERK phosphorylation is an artifact of the optogenetic tool, not real Ras signaling
The pathway responds only to the total number of photons, regardless of timing
questions.explanation: This optogenetic experiment reveals the MAPK cascade's temporal filtering properties. The cascade acts as a low-pass filter/temporal integrator: (1) Each pulse of Ras activity initiates a wave of phosphorylation through Raf → MEK → ERK. (2) Dephosphorylation at each tier has finite kinetics (determined by phosphatase activity): Raf deactivation (minutes), MEK dephosphorylation (minutes), ERK dephosphorylation (~5-10 min). (3) If the interval between pulses is shorter than the deactivation time, the next pulse arrives before complete deactivation, maintaining a 'floor' of activity — similar to temporal summation in neurons. (4) The resulting time-averaged ERK output is approximately proportional to the 'duty cycle' (fraction of time Ras is ON): continuous (100%) = high, 1/5 (20%) = moderate, 1/10 (10%) = low. (5) A single pulse (rows 4-5) fully deactivates by 30 min, confirming the system has no permanent 'memory' but does have finite relaxation kinetics. This experiment demonstrates that the MAPK cascade's multi-tiered architecture provides not only amplification but also temporal signal processing — converting digital (on-off) Ras pulses into an analog (graded) ERK output. This has implications for understanding how cells decode pulsatile growth factor release.

questions.question:
A drug screen identifies a compound that blocks TNF-alpha-induced NF-kappaB activation. To determine where in the pathway the drug acts, researchers measure:

| Measurement | TNF-alpha alone | TNF-alpha + Drug |
|-------------|----------------|------------------|
| TNF-R1 surface expression | Normal | Normal |
| IKK kinase activity | High | Low |
| IkappaBalpha degradation | Complete | Blocked |
| p65 nuclear translocation | Strong | Blocked |
| NF-kappaB reporter | 20-fold | 2-fold |
| Direct IKK activation (constitutively active IKK-CA) | 25-fold reporter | 25-fold reporter |

The drug blocks IKK activity but does not affect constitutively active IKK. At what level does the drug act?
options: The drug directly inhibits NF-kappaB DNA binding in the nucleus
The drug directly inhibits the proteasome, preventing IkappaBalpha degradation
The drug blocks TNF-alpha from binding TNF-R1
The drug acts upstream of IKK but downstream of TNF-R1, likely inhibiting a signaling intermediate (TRADD, TRAF2, RIP1, or TAK1) required for IKK activation, without directly targeting IKK itself
questions.explanation: Systematic epistasis analysis reveals the drug's mechanism. Key deductions: (1) TNF-R1 expression is normal → drug doesn't affect receptor levels or ligand binding. (2) IKK activity is reduced → drug blocks IKK activation, not a downstream step. (3) IkappaBalpha degradation and p65 nuclear translocation are blocked → consistent with IKK inhibition (IKK phosphorylates IkappaBalpha for degradation). (4) CRITICAL: Constitutively active IKK (IKK-CA, which bypasses all upstream activation steps) fully activates the NF-kappaB reporter even in the presence of the drug (25-fold, same as without drug). This means the drug does NOT directly inhibit IKK catalytic activity — if it did, IKK-CA would also be blocked. Instead, the drug must block an upstream step required for IKK activation. (5) Since TNF-R1 is normal but IKK is not activated, the drug likely targets a signaling intermediate between TNF-R1 and IKK: candidates include TRADD (adaptor), TRAF2 (E3 ligase for K63-Ub), RIP1/RIPK1 (kinase/scaffold), or TAK1 (the MAP3K that directly phosphorylates IKK). Further experiments with constitutively active versions of each intermediate would pinpoint the exact target.

questions.question:
Western blots of Akt phosphorylation (pSer473) are performed in cells treated with insulin in the presence of various inhibitors:

| Condition | pAkt level |
|-----------|------------|
| Control (no insulin) | - |
| Insulin | +++ |
| Insulin + wortmannin (PI3K inhib) | - |
| Insulin + rapamycin (mTORC1 inhib) | +++ |
| Insulin + Torin1 (mTOR inhib, both mTORC1+mTORC2) | - |
| Insulin + MK-2206 (allosteric Akt inhib) | - |

Rapamycin does not block pAkt (Ser473), but Torin1 does. What does this reveal about which mTOR complex phosphorylates Akt at Ser473?
options: mTORC1 phosphorylates Akt at Ser473
Rapamycin activates Akt through a feedback loop

mTORC2 (not mTORC1) is the kinase that phosphorylates Akt at Ser473; rapamycin selectively inhibits mTORC1 (leaving mTORC2 intact, so pAkt persists), while Torin1 inhibits both mTOR complexes (blocking mTORC2, eliminating pAkt)
Neither mTOR complex is involved; Torin1 has off-target effects on PI3K
questions.explanation: This pharmacological dissection elegantly identifies mTORC2 as the Ser473 kinase for Akt. The key comparison: rapamycin (which specifically inhibits mTORC1 by disrupting Raptor-mTOR interaction) does NOT reduce pAkt-Ser473, demonstrating mTORC1 is not the relevant kinase. Torin1 (an ATP-competitive mTOR inhibitor that blocks both mTORC1 and mTORC2) DOES eliminate pAkt-Ser473, implicating mTOR catalytic activity in pAkt. Since the difference between rapamycin and Torin1 is mTORC2 inhibition, mTORC2 must be the Ser473 kinase. This is consistent with genetic evidence: Rictor (an mTORC2-specific component) knockout abolishes Akt Ser473 phosphorylation. The wortmannin control confirms PI3K is required upstream (for PIP3-mediated Akt membrane recruitment). MK-2206 confirms Akt identity. Interestingly, prolonged rapamycin treatment (days, not hours) CAN reduce pAkt in some cell types because it prevents new mTORC2 assembly (mTOR is shared between both complexes), but acute rapamycin treatment (as shown here) spares pre-formed mTORC2. This distinction has clinical implications: Torin1-type catalytic mTOR inhibitors may be more effective anti-cancer agents than rapamycin because they block both mTORC1 (cell growth) and mTORC2 (cell survival via Akt).

questions.question: You discover that a transcription factor (TF-X) is activated by two different signaling pathways (Pathway A and Pathway B). To determine whether the pathways activate TF-X by the same or different mechanisms, which experimental approach is most informative?
options: Simply measure TF-X mRNA levels after stimulating each pathway
Measure TF-X protein levels by Western blot after each pathway activation
Overexpress TF-X and see if it is constitutively active

Map the specific post-translational modifications (phosphorylation sites, acetylation) on TF-X induced by each pathway using mass spectrometry; if Pathway A phosphorylates different residues than Pathway B, or if they induce different modifications (phosphorylation vs. acetylation), this reveals distinct activation mechanisms that may produce different transcriptional outputs
questions.explanation: Post-translational modification (PTM) mapping by mass spectrometry is the most informative approach for distinguishing activation mechanisms. The rationale: a transcription factor can be activated by different modifications that lead to different functional outcomes. For example, CREB can be phosphorylated at Ser133 by PKA (cAMP pathway), CaMKIV (Ca2+ pathway), or RSK2 (MAPK pathway). While all three modifications activate CREB's interaction with CBP/p300, additional pathway-specific modifications on CREB's regulatory domains can modulate which co-factors are recruited and which genes are ultimately activated. The experimental approach: (1) Stimulate Pathway A or Pathway B separately; (2) Immunoprecipitate TF-X; (3) Analyze by LC-MS/MS to identify all modified residues; (4) Use site-directed mutagenesis (Ser→Ala for each phosphosite) to determine which modifications are essential for each pathway's transcriptional output; (5) Use phospho-specific antibodies to monitor pathway-specific modifications in real-time. If different pathways modify TF-X at different sites, this creates a combinatorial PTM code that can generate pathway-specific transcriptional programs from a single transcription factor — a mechanism for signal integration at the level of transcription factor regulation.

questions.question: Synthetic biology approaches are being used to engineer custom signaling circuits. To create an AND gate (requires both Signal A AND Signal B for output), which design principle would you use?
options: Use a single receptor that responds to either signal independently
Use two promoters that each independently drive the same output gene
Express a single kinase that responds to both signals equally

Split a transcription factor into two halves, each fused to a different signal-responsive dimerization domain; only when both signals are present do the halves come together to reconstitute the functional transcription factor and activate the output gene
questions.explanation: The split-protein complementation approach is an elegant design for AND gate logic in synthetic signaling circuits. The concept: (1) Split a transcription factor (e.g., split-Gal4 in yeast, or split-dCas9 activator) into N-terminal and C-terminal halves, each non-functional alone. (2) Fuse the N-terminal half to a domain that responds to Signal A (e.g., a rapamycin-inducible FKBP domain). (3) Fuse the C-terminal half to a domain that responds to Signal B (e.g., an ABA-inducible ABI domain). (4) When only Signal A is present, only the N-half is activated but cannot function alone. When only Signal B is present, only the C-half is activated but cannot function alone. (5) When BOTH signals are present, both halves are simultaneously activated and brought together (via a complementary dimerization or proximity mechanism), reconstituting functional transcription factor activity → output gene activation. This creates a strict AND gate: output = 1 only if A = 1 AND B = 1. Other synthetic logic gates (OR, NOT, NOR, NAND) can be built using similar modular design principles, enabling construction of complex decision-making circuits in engineered cells for therapeutic applications (e.g., CAR-T cells that only attack cells expressing two tumor antigens).

questions.question:
Researchers perform a phosphoproteomics experiment, measuring global tyrosine phosphorylation changes after EGF stimulation at multiple time points:

| Protein | 1 min (fold change) | 5 min | 15 min | 60 min |
|---------|--------------------|---------|---------|---------|
| EGFR | 50 | 30 | 10 | 2 |
| Shc | 25 | 20 | 8 | 1 |
| ERK1/2 | 5 | 15 | 8 | 2 |
| Gab1 | 8 | 20 | 15 | 5 |
| STAT3 | 2 | 8 | 12 | 8 |
| SHP2 | 3 | 10 | 12 | 6 |

EGFR and Shc peak early (1 min) while STAT3 and SHP2 peak late (15 min). What does this temporal ordering reveal about the signaling network architecture?
options: Later-peaking proteins are from a completely separate signaling pathway unrelated to EGFR
The early-peaking proteins are artifacts of the mass spectrometry measurement
All proteins are phosphorylated simultaneously; the timing differences are measurement noise

The temporal ordering reflects the network topology: proximal substrates (EGFR autophosphorylation, direct substrate Shc) peak earliest, while downstream effectors requiring multi-step recruitment (STAT3 requires JAK activation, SHP2 requires Gab1 scaffold assembly) peak later, revealing the signal propagation sequence through the network
questions.explanation: Temporal phosphoproteomics reveals the signal propagation sequence through a signaling network, essentially mapping the pathway topology in real time. Early responders (1 min peak): EGFR autophosphorylation is the initiating event (maximal at 1 min, then declines due to phosphatase activity, receptor internalization, and ubiquitin-mediated degradation). Shc is a direct EGFR substrate (binds pTyr via PTB domain), so its phosphorylation closely tracks EGFR activation. Intermediate responders (5 min peak): ERK peaks at 5 min, consistent with the time needed for the multi-step Grb2→SOS→Ras→Raf→MEK→ERK cascade (each enzymatic step adds ~30-60 seconds). Gab1 peaks at 5 min because it requires initial EGFR-mediated phosphorylation and subsequent recruitment of additional signaling molecules (PI3K, SHP2). Late responders (15 min peak): STAT3 phosphorylation peaks latest because it requires: EGFR activation → Src family kinase activation → JAK activation → STAT3 recruitment and phosphorylation, a multi-step process. SHP2 peaks with Gab1 because SHP2 binds phospho-Gab1 via its SH2 domains. The sequential decline of all proteins reflects the collective action of phosphatases (PTP1B, SHP1, PP2A), receptor downregulation (Cbl-mediated ubiquitination and lysosomal degradation), and negative feedback (MAPK phosphatases, Sprouty). This temporal analysis is a powerful tool for understanding pathway architecture and identifying rate-limiting steps.
